content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <rdf:RDF  xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"  xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/"  xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"  xmlns:prism="http://prismstandard.org/namespaces/1.2/basic/">       <channel rdf:about="http://journal.tei-c.org/index.php/journal">     <title>Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative: Announcements</title>   <link>http://journal.tei-c.org/index.php/journal</link>          <description><p>The <a title="jTEI home" href="http://jtei.revues.org/"><em><cite>Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative</cite></em></a> is the official journal of the Text Encoding Initiative Consortium. It publishes selected papers from the annual TEI Conference and Members' Meeting and special issues based on topics or themes of interest to the community or in conjunction with special events or meetings associated with TEI. Its contents are rigorously peer-reviewed.</p> <p>The objectives of the journal are to disseminate as widely as possible information about the TEI and its applications to scholarship. The <cite>Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative</cite> publishes state-of-the-art reports on electronic textual editing, current trends in TEI encoding, and new use cases for TEI. It provides a forum for articles on the discussion of the interface between the TEI and other communities, and more generally of the role of technological standards in the digital humanities. As a peer-reviewed, regularly published journal, it is the first point of entry to the latest scholarship relating to not only the TEI but also various fields typically associated with TEI practice&mdash;for example, digital scholarly editing, linguistic analysis, corpora creation, and much newer areas such as mass digitization, semantic web research, and editing within virtual worlds.</p><p>The journal is published at <a href="http://jtei.revues.org/">jtei.revues.org</a> as part of <a id="lh9i" title="Revues.org" href="http://www.revues.org/">Revues.org</a>, the web platform for journals and book collections of Cl&eacute;o, the <a href="http://cleo.cnrs.fr/">French Centre for Open Electronic Publishing</a>.</p></description>        <dc:language>en-US</dc:language>      <items>       <rdf:Seq>     <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/24"/>    </rdf:Seq>       <rdf:Seq>     <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/23"/>    </rdf:Seq>       <rdf:Seq>     <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/22"/>    </rdf:Seq>       <rdf:Seq>     <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/21"/>    </rdf:Seq>       <rdf:Seq>     <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/20"/>    </rdf:Seq>       <rdf:Seq>     <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/18"/>    </rdf:Seq>      </items>  </channel>   <item rdf:about="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/24">     <title>CFP: Issue 9 of the Journal of the Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative: 2014 Conference Issue</title>   <link>http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/24</link>        <description><p>The Journal of the Text Encoding Initia</p><p>tive (JTEI, &lt;<a href="http://jtei.revues.org/">http://jtei.revues.org/</a>&gt;) is now soliciting contributions for its <strong>2014 Conference Issue</strong>. We invite all presenters from the 2014 Conference in Evanston to submit articles based on their presentations through the submission process on <a href="/">journal.tei-c.org</a>:<br /><br />&lt;<a href="/journal/author/submit/1">http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/author/submit/1</a>&gt;<br /><br />If you have been an author or reviewer before, you should be able to use your existing login; otherwise you'll need to create an account. For "Section", choose "Issue 9 (papers from the 2014 conference)".<br /><br />Note that we have recently adopted a new Author Agreement based on open access principles which leaves copyright with the author rather than vesting it in the Journal, giving you much greater control over your work:<br /><br />&lt;<a href="http://www.tei-c.org/jTEI/jtei_author_agreement_CC.pdf">http://www.tei-c.org/jTEI/jtei_author_agreement_CC.pdf</a>&gt;<br /><br />Detailed guidelines for authors are available here:<br /><br />&lt;<a href="/journal/about/submissions#authorGuidelines">http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/about/submissions#authorGuidelines</a>&gt;<br /><br />Please feel free to contact any of the editors with specific questions about articles or the submission process.<br /><br />Note that the <a href="/journal/announcement/view/21">"TEI and Materiality" issue CfP</a> is also still open, although this issue is now designated as Issue 10.</p><p>John Walsh</p></description>     <dc:creator>Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative</dc:creator>   <dc:date>2015-02-03</dc:date>  </item>  <item rdf:about="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/23">     <title>First two articles from Issue 8 published</title>   <link>http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/23</link>        <description>Issue 8 of the Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative (Selected Papers from the 2013 TEI Conference) is going to be larger than any previous issue, and so we are publishing it on a "rolling" basis as articles are completed. The first two articles have now been published on the Journal site, just as you were looking around for something good to read in your vacation: <br /> <br /><a class="moz-txt-link-rfc2396E" href="http://jtei.revues.org/1025">&lt;http://jtei.revues.org/1025&gt;</a> <br /> <br />Giliola Barbero and Francesca Trasselli: <br />Manus OnLine and the Text Encoding Initiative Schema <br /><a class="moz-txt-link-rfc2396E" href="http://jtei.revues.org/1054">&lt;http://jtei.revues.org/1054&gt;</a> <br /> <br />Roberto Rosselli Del Turco, Giancarlo Buomprisco, Chiara Di Pietro, Julia Kenny, Raffaele Masotti, and Jacopo Pugliese: <br />Edition Visualization Technology: A Simple Tool to Visualize TEI-based Digital Editions <br /><a class="moz-txt-link-rfc2396E" href="http://jtei.revues.org/1077">&lt;http://jtei.revues.org/1077&gt;</a> <br /> <br />Many thanks to our guest editors, Arianna Ciula and Fabio Ciotti, for their work on this issue, alongside the rest of the team (John Walsh, General Editor, and Ron Van den Branden, Technical Editor). <br /> <br />Many more articles from this issue will be appearing over the next couple of months. Also, don't forget the Call for Papers for Issue 9 which is currently open: <br /> <br /><a class="moz-txt-link-rfc2396E" href="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/21">&lt;http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/21&gt;</a> <br /> <br />Best wishes for the holidays, <br /> <br />Martin Holmes <br />(Managing Editor, JTEI)</description>     <dc:creator>Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative</dc:creator>   <dc:date>2014-12-29</dc:date>  </item>  <item rdf:about="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/22">     <title>Issue 7 published</title>   <link>http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/22</link>        <description><p><a href="http://jtei.revues.org/948" target="_blank">Issue 7</a> of the Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative has been published. Entitled &lsquo;Reaching Out, Opting In, this issue was based on an open call for papers. The four articles in this issue deal with several meta concerns of the community and make for provocative and thoughtful reading.</p><p>This issue is the first that makes available the TEI source texts for all articles. To download the source for an article, follow the link 'TEI source' in the 'Attachments' section at the end.</p></description>     <dc:creator>Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative</dc:creator>   <dc:date>2014-11-15</dc:date>  </item>  <item rdf:about="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/21">     <title>CFP: Issue 10 of the Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative</title>   <link>http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/21</link>        <description>Much recent humanities scholarship expresses renewed interest and attention in material culture and the physical artifact. Recent literary and cultural studies are rich with articles and books focused on materiality or the "material turn" in humanities research. Since its earliest versions, the TEI Guidelines have provided mechanisms for recording details about the physical artifact--for example, the @rend attribute may used to record layout, design, typographic, and other graphic dimensions of the source artifact. However, with the release of TEI P5 in 2007 and in the ongoing development and refinement of P5, new and more robust mechanisms for recording details about the material artifact were introduced to the TEI Guidelines. The `rendition` element, along with the `@rend` `@rendition` and `@style` attributes provide a robust infrastructure for recording the graphic and design features of a document. The `msDesc` element and related elements and attributes provide mechanisms for providing extensive detail about the physical attributes of manuscripts, books, and other text bearing objects. The `facsimile` element and related features provide an infrastructure for fuller integration of facsimile images with the encoded text. <br /><br />The editors of the Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative, the official journal of the TEI Consortium, are delighted to announce a call for papers for a special issue that focuses on <strong>TEI and Materiality</strong>. For this issue we welcome articles that explore the relationship between the TEI Guidelines, the encoded document, and the material object. <br /><br />Example topics that might be discussed include:<br /><br /><ul><li>Conceptual and theoretical discussions of the relationship between the encoded text and the material object</li><li>Discussion of interfaces that present details about materiality (beyond the standard combination of encoded text and facsimile page image)</li><li>Innovative uses of the TEI Guidelines to model material aspects of the document</li><li>Proposed new features for the TEI Guidelines that would provide further support for modeling material aspects of the text-bearing object.</li><li>The use of TEI in combination with other standards and technologies to support the investigation of materiality</li></ul><br />Submissions are accepted in two categories: research articles of 5,000 to 7,000 words and shorter articles reflecting new research or new tools/services of 2000-4000 words. Both may include images and multimedia content. Author guidelines are available at <a href="/journal/about/submissions#authorGuidelines">http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/about/submissions#authorGuidelines</a><br /><br />The Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative, a peer-reviewed open-access publication hosted by Revues.org, is the official journal of the TEI Consortium. Closing date for submissions to this issue is <strong>31 March 2015</strong>.<br /><br />If you have any questions, please contact John Walsh &lt;<a href="mailto:jawalsh@indiana.edu">jawalsh@indiana.edu</a>&gt;</description>     <dc:creator>Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative</dc:creator>   <dc:date>2014-09-12</dc:date>  </item>  <item rdf:about="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/20">     <title>Issue 6 published</title>   <link>http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/20</link>        <description>This issue contains the following articles:<br /> <br /><ul><li> Encoding the Discipline: English Graduate Student Reflections on Working with TEI&nbsp; by Maura Ives, Victor Del Hierro, Bailey Kelsey, Laura Catherine Smith, and Christina Sumners</li><li>Encoding Financial Records for Historical Research&nbsp; by Kathryn Tomasek and Syd Bauman</li><li>Stationers' Register Online: A Case Study of a Byte-Reduced TEI Schema for Digitization (tei_corset)&nbsp; by James Cummings and Pip Willcox</li><li>Rebooting TEI Pointers by Hugh A. Cayless</li><li>Resolving the Durand Conundrum by Lou Burnard </li></ul></description>     <dc:creator>Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative</dc:creator>   <dc:date>2014-01-27</dc:date>  </item>  <item rdf:about="http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/18">     <title>Issue 5 published</title>   <link>http://journal.tei-c.org/journal/announcement/view/18</link>        <description>The issue contains six articles that deals with the TEI as infrastructure from several different perspectives: <br /> <br /><ul><li>PhiloLogic4: An Abstract TEI Query System by Timothy Allen, Clovis Gladstone, and Richard Whaling</li><li>TAPAS: Building a TEI Publishing and Repository Service by Julia Flanders and Scott Hamlin</li><li>Islandora and TEI: Current and Emerging Applications/Approaches by Kirsta Stapelfeldt and Donald Moses</li><li>TEI and Project Bamboo by Quinn Dombrowski and Seth Denbo</li><li>TextGrid, TEXTvre, and DARIAH: Sustainability of Infrastructures for Textual Scholarship&nbsp; by Mark Hedges, Heike Neuroth, Kathleen M. Smith, Tobias Blanke, Laurent Romary, Marc K&uuml;ster, and Malcolm Illingworth</li><li>The Evolution of the Text Encoding Initiative: From Research Project to Research Infrastructure by Lou Burnard</li></ul></description>     <dc:creator>Journal of the Text Encoding Initiative</dc:creator>   <dc:date>2013-06-26</dc:date>  </item>  </rdf:RDF>
